#### Overall hits, false alarms (FAs), and recognition

```{r, echo=FALSE, results = FALSE, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE, cache=TRUE, fig.show='hide'}
##################################################################################################################
##  Exp3 Hits:                                                                                                  ##
##################################################################################################################
##  Two-way mixed ANOVA:
    exp3__prop.hit.aov <- afex::aov_ez('id', 'prop.hit', fun_aggregate = mean, exp3__prop.hit, 
                                       between = "resp_option", within = 'stim',
                                       anova_table=list(correction = "none", es = "none"))
##  Mauchlys test of sphericity:
    exp3__prop.hit.aov__sphericity <- test_sphericity(exp3__prop.hit.aov)
    exp3__prop.hit.aov__sphericity <- exp3__prop.hit.aov__sphericity[1,2]
      
##  Assumption of sphericity violated (p<.05), so apply Greenhouse-Geisser correction:
    exp3__prop.hit.aov <- afex::aov_ez('id', 'prop.hit', fun_aggregate = mean, exp3__prop.hit, 
                                       between = "resp_option", within = 'stim',
                                       anova_table=list(correction = "GG", es = "ges"))
#-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
##  Significant main effect of RESPONSE OPTION, so perform independent samples (Welch's) t-test: 
    exp3__prop.hit__ttest__rfg.rfbg <- exp3__prop.hit %>% t.test(prop.hit~resp_option, paired=FALSE, data = .)
    
##  Significant main effect of STIMULI FORMAT, so perform paired contrasts:
    exp3__prop.hit__pairs__stim.format <- pairs(emmeans(exp3__prop.hit.aov, c("stim")), adjust = "holm")
    
##  Get means:
    exp3__prop.hit__stim.means <- emmeans(exp3__prop.hit.aov, ~stim)
    exp3__prop.hit.means__word <- summary(exp3__prop.hit__stim.means)$emmean[1] %>% round(2)
    exp3__prop.hit.means__grey.drawing <- summary(exp3__prop.hit__stim.means)$emmean[2] %>% round(2)
    exp3__prop.hit.means__grey.photo <- summary(exp3__prop.hit__stim.means)$emmean[3] %>% round
    exp3__prop.hit__resp.option <- emmeans(exp3__prop.hit.aov, ~resp_option)
    exp3__prop.hit.means__RFG <- summary(exp3__prop.hit__resp.option)$emmean[2] %>% round(2)
    exp3__prop.hit.means__RFBG <- summary(exp3__prop.hit__resp.option)$emmean[1] %>% round(2)
##  Format contrasts for report:
    exp3__prop.hit__ttest__word.drawing <- 
        papaja::apa_print(exp3__prop.hit__pairs__stim.format[1])$statistic$word_greydrawing
    exp3__prop.hit__ttest__word.photo <- 
        papaja::apa_print(exp3__prop.hit__pairs__stim.format[2])$statistic$word_greyphoto
    exp3__prop.hit__ttest__drawing.photo <- 
        papaja::apa_print(exp3__prop.hit__pairs__stim.format[3])$statistic$greydrawing_greyphoto
```

Throughout each of the conducted ANOVAs, there was consistently a significant main effect of stimuli format: mean proportion of hits [`r apa::anova_apa(exp3__prop.hit.aov, effect = "stim", format = "rmarkdown", print = FALSE)`]

words (*M* = `r exp3__prop.hit.means__word`) 
grey drawings (*M* = `r exp3__prop.hit.means__grey.drawing`), 
`r apa::apa(a, format = "rmarkdown", print = FALSE)` 

`r 



Results example:

Data were analysed using repeated measures ANOVA, with encoding trial type (draw, visualize, write) as a within-participants factor. Results indi- cated a significant main effect of encoding trial type, F(2, 54)=8.23, MSE=.04, p,.005, Î·2 = .23. Paired-samples t tests using Bonferroni adjusted alpha levels of .0167 per test (.05/3) revealed that this was driven by significantly better recall for drawn trial types than for write trial types, t(27)=4.62, SE=.04, p,.001, d= 0.87, and marginally better recall for drawn than for visualized trial types, t(27) = 2.20, SE = .06, p = .037, d = 0.42. The difference in recall between visualize and write trial types was not significant, t(27)=1.58, SE=.05, p=.126, d=0.30 (see Figure 3).
